narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This course could be greatly improved with better speakers/presentations. The speakers were okay, but there tended to be a lot of overlap in what was discussed. A clearer approach might help. I also would have liked to have more non-Jonathan Rose Companies speakers. And it would have been nice to have one key reading assignment for each class that could give us a simple overview of the topic, with all the additional reading provided as a supplement. It was hard to know where to start and the supplied reading was too much for a 1 credit course.

Every speaker who came thought they had to give us a background on climate change. We are masters students at FES. We KNOW about climate change. We were taking the class because we wanted to learn about HOW to design land use projects to minimize CO2 emissions. I hoped to gain some practical knowledge from the course but didn't. I hoped I'd be walking away from the course with some examples of really creative and innovative projects but I'm not.

Question 9: There was one field trip but I was unable to attend.Question 10: The material taught in the class doesn't fall under my primary field of interest, but I shared the information with friends who I thought would be interested, and it facilitated some great conversation and excitement about the topics.
1. There were virtually no readings2. Guest lecturers ran the gammit from "magnigicent clarity" to "dense fog;" the average, as well as the organizing professor, Daniel Hernandez, was around 2
I loved the student presentations at the end.
Meeting planning practitioners.
Our TA who worked tirelessly without pay to organize the course and field trip.
Hearing from a variety of experts in the field
Daniel is really great, i enjoyed his presentations and thoughts/reactions to speakers. some the speakers were really engaging
Talking with Daniel Hernandez and other speakers about general topics. The field trip to the South Bronx.
Meeting at night so I was able to have a free day.
An extra credit for very little work. It got canceled at least 25% of the days; this is actually not good, but given a busy semester, I appreciated the surprise free time.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: better coordination with the other land use planning course

Communication with speakers on what the POINT of the course is. They should come in really prepared to know who their audience is and what kind of information we are looking for. It's not enough to invite cool people-- they need to be guided.
speakers not being redundant and not pitching the same basic education presentation that they give to planning boards - we need to advance the topic, advance our learning, get after solutions..
Needs a broader range of land use topics: MTR, agriculture, other topics.
Coordination among guest speakers to reduce redundancies.

-This course was offered during the same semester as John Nolon's "Land Use Planning and Practice." It is an important topic, but the two classes have too much overlap. Indeed, early in the semester they were covering the same topics on the same weeks--though this got fixed as time went on. A class like Nolon's is much more useful than this class, and so this one shouldn't be offered again.-Too many guest lecturers canceled, and the professor himself couldn't make it a lot.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: High
I e-mailed the instructor once and never got a reply.
Both were very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am very interested in local action on climate change, so land use is critical. There isn't enough work on this area at FES.I've always wanted more courses on it. But this semester there were two courses and they said they same things. Either there isn't any more to say, or this course was just not trying to break any new ground; I think the latter is more likely.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in planning and wanted to hear from and have the chance to network with many people in the field.
The TA told me it was her favorite course at FES last year. I was also looking for a 1-credit course. I think there should be more 1-credit options.
This course was offered last year and I learned a lot. I took it again in the hopes of hearing new guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not AT ALL
Unfortunately some of the speakers were too redundant and some of the topics not as innovative as I would like to hear about. The time commitment and expectation for a one credit course was fair.
No, I would not say it was one of the better courses I have taken at FES.
No. It was a waste of time.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: NO!
Somewhat -
No. I learned little .

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Ask to have input on which speakers come and which topics are addressed. The course should be more student interest driven so that people remain engaged - hearing the same story told by three different people in three different ways isn't what you need. Daniel is great though and would like to have more conversation in the class.
Involve any contacts you have with outside land use professionals or experts.
I would not take this course along with other land use planning courses...that might get too repetitive.
Don't take this course if you are taking, or have taken, another course in land use planning. It is a very basic introduction.
